content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												The only good thing about this game is Mors' voice acting. It is epic and it makes Mors a bad♥♥♥♥♥ In fact Mors is a really cool character that I'd like to see in a game similar to Witcher 3 but that is where the good things end. The game is a poorly made and is very badly optimised. Combat is uninteresting and uninspired and is nothing like DA:O which is a great game. The story is a joke to Game of Thrones universe. It is as if it was written for a bad fairly tale with stupid plot twists that are seen from miles away. Varys looks like a fool in this game, they ruined him persona (other characters from the series/books look foolish too). Cersei isn't even voiced by Lena Headey. And most importantly, the game just feels awkward. I mean main characters are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Like badly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and completely cliche. Especially the Red Priest. The animation is completely out of place! I mean the hand gestures that are frequently used by 2 main brutal characters that look like they are waving their hand and showing the index finger and saying "heeey Gurl" (all they need to add here is the circular head movement with the neck being completely moitionless) are just outright immersion breaking.  I mean they do it all the time when they try to act tough. But instead of looking tough they look like they are homosexual and it just makes it all silly. Not to mention lots of other animations that are not supposed to happen!There is not much to say here except that it fails both as an RPG and a GoT story. I would avoid it at all costs even if you are a fan of either or both. And this is coming from a guy who plays old games on regular basis, who loves indie and RPGs like Morrowind and DA:O and a guy who loves GoT books and series.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 10, 2013
												Game of Thrones title is fully earned here - evil will triumph and the innocent blood will grease the gears of political schemes.Writing is the main course here - the plot takes place shortly after Robert Baratheon's death, when the king's bast... errm... illegitimate children are being hunted. We have two main characters with separate storylines and motives, but they will be forced to take part in the political events. The atmosphere is very bleak, treachery lurks everywhere. The game features some of the most disturbing scenes in gaming - done so well, that the worst one isn't even graphic.There are a lot of smaller and bigger choices to make, the consequences are often non-direct or delayed - but they have impact on the plot.The game is off-putting at the beginning - the visuals are outdated (though some of the textures, armors etc. look weirdly good) and the combat feels slow and boring. But if only you'll stay a bit longer, hopefully you'll find yourself in the story's grip. The graphics will still be awful, but servicable. Combat will pick up a bit though once you'll learn more skills and get more stamina to use them - it will still be a bit boring as it's very tactical and focues on disabling and exploiting enemies (at higher difficulty levels it's very challenging).Get the Beyond of Wall DLC if you decide to play the game - it's a short prequel and it's great.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												far from the bad game everybody says it is, unless you don't care at all for story and ethics of choices.it reminded me strongly of mass effect, though that was better drawn and the playing was more fun and the world and quests bit more interesting, but game of thrones beats it in plot twists, and matches its moral/wthical dillema presentation, though i think there's always an inherent goof/bad ending, but the choices are truly open and change the path of the game.the voice acting was also sub par. not being able to follow with the many names also takes away from the game, if you know the GOT universe this would be 10 times more enjoyable i guess.it's also longer than my liking, other people i'm sure like their games longer.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Its a great roleplaying game, plain and simple.  If you are a fan of the Game of Thrones series like I am, and like roleplaying games, its just plain neat.I really am enjoying being in the nights watch and seeing the ominous, thrilling wall that goes on forever.The combat is tactical not action.  The game does say that in the description, but I thought it would be somewhat twitch based, it is not.  You choose the actions of the character and they carry them out in real time, but you can pause any time and change and/or que up orders.Its a role playing game, which means you do get to build up your character, choose attributes and skills, buy, find, and equip different weapons and armor.  I love it.  Exploration pays off in finding new items, etc.The graphics are fantastic at the highest settings and at 1600 by 900 resolution.  I know that people criticized the graphics for the Xbox, but the computer version to me at least, captures the world perfectly.The dialogue and story is game of thrones, that simple.  Horrible actions, rough words, and intigue everywhere.  Do not let your children play this game.  The first quest is caused by some horrible, R rated actions.A few things could be better.You have to almost be on top of an item before you see it.  For example, you may see a bunch of crates across the room, but you have to walk over there and almost be touching them before you get an icon that there is something to grab.The game appears to be fairly linear.  I'm very early in the game, but its not a wide open world to explore, its more of a tight knit story to follow.  There are sidequests, and several neat choices in the dialogue, but this is a more linear game.Needs more actors from the series.  The only voices that I believe are in it from the series are Varas and the commander of the Night's watch, thats it.  Since this takes place parallel to season 1, there are so many others we could have met.  I don't know what other characters may be around, but even if we get to meet them, they won't be the same voices.Anyways, I don't what was up with the Xbox version, but the pc special edition version is a great game if you would like to enjoy Westeros for a little bit while waiting for season 5.  Right now its on sale for 5 bucks.  Its a steal!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												This game's gotten some good and bad reviews, and I'm not 100% sure why the bad reviews except for maybe a bad port to PC. There is a solution for that: it's called a controller. It took me all of about two seconds to realize I needed to pull mine out of the drawer and connect it in order to have a better experience with this game. Do that and remember you're playing an RPG (because fighting is a pause-and-plan affair), and it's a good and immersive game in the style of the books or the show. You'll start as one character, a member of the Night's Watch, play a chapter, then switch to a noble--with a twist (the screenshot should clue you in to what the twist is)--and by about the fourth or fifth chapter, you start to see how they're tying it together. Story-wise, it's done in Game of Thrones style, combat-wise, it's a standard RPG, pause-and-plan with a means of controlling various members of your party and a means of regenerating energy for attacks without requiring potions (though they are available if you want them).I highly, HIGHLY recommend a controller if you have one because without one, it's a bit of a hassle to deal with clunky controls. With a controller, though, it's a decent game with a decent story...though a bit too 'on rails' with a lot of invisible walls preventing players from really getting to explore some areas. As small as some maps are, the invisible walls aren't really necessary. It is worth noting, however, that some of the main characters, such as Mormont and Varys are voiced by the actors who portray those characters on the show, though Cersei is not voiced in the game by Lena Headey--which is a bit of a disappointment after hearing James Cosmo as Mormont and Conleth Hill as Varys.  Clunky PC controls requiring a controller and invisible walls make me only rate it about a 7 overall.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												I personally went in looking for an average or poor game, after reading the reviews, but after playing it for 30 mins it dawned on me that it's actually a pretty great RPG with a superb story. From really the start of the game it will pull you in and get you invested in the two main heroes and their cause. And will give you the "game of thrones" treatment story wise until the very end. The game does have it's flaws - and i would suggest you watch at least a minor youtube clip to see that you can handle the a bit strange 3rd person view. Also the AI is pretty dumb in most situations, but the combat, once you get used to it, feels solid and challenging enough to not get boring, and the AI being predicatble can be considered a good thing, as it allows youto build up your own strategy of how to deal with different groups of enemies. Plays well with KB/Mouse, no problems at all. And the graphics options and toggles that you would expect a PC game to have are all there.Final thoughts:Great game, with a great story, that looks a bit dated, but doesn't have any major glaring bugs and accomplishes what it sets out to do, which is tell you a story while giving you enough gameplay in between to make you feel apart of the story and that what you do matters.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												The Critic-Reviews on this game do such an injustice based on a 5 min play session. This game has a very intriguing Story that kept me invested in the game. NOTHING was phoned in about the plot, it was well thought out from start to finish based on the books and using some special character faces from Season 1 of the TV series. The videos are short and keep you in suspense for the anticipating blood bath to come. The combat in the game is nothing revolutionary but it is fun and makes sense. A major complaint is that this game is clunky and glitch but I have only had 2 glitches in 40 hours of play and both were resolved easily without reloading… in fact I get more glitches with Call of Duty then I do with this game. This game isn’t state-of-the-art GOLD by any means but if you can get past the fact that not all games have the budget of Halo Reach and CoD Ghost then this is a solid game that looks great for what it is. Character Development is very well balanced… I never found myself dominating over groups of men and I did hit a few points were I had to try a few times to beat a special bad guy so the challenge part of the game is perfect. I am extremely satisfied with this game and the money I spent to have it.

If you go in with low expectations, ignore the limits this game has and focus on immersing yourself in the characters and enjoying the story then this game can be quite entertaining.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Intruiging storyline following two men, both vassals of Tywin Lannister, who fled from their past after Robert Baratheon's rebellion. In each mainstory conversation you will get different options on what tosay, how to react or what to do, all which will effect the story and the the NPC:s opinion of you. The voice acting, on the other hand, is terrible. Everyone speak with monotone voices lacking of emotions as if the actors just read the script into the mic instead of acting it out. In an RPG containing more intruiging story than combat, the voice acting is important and Cyanide Studios should've tried getting better actors.The combat is inspired på the KotOR series. You have a skillset and you queue up your skills to execute combos and deal as much damage as possible. The combat part is well done and works fine. You upgrade your skill tree and choose yourself if you want a lot of different active skills, buff yourself with passives or use a combination of both.Some hitbox glitches can be found as well as a bad choice of camera angles during cutscenes, but apart from that the game was good. Not great or the best I've ever played, but certainly good and worth trying.7/10

So many plot twists, so many suprises, what a good game and not deserving of its negative reviews.  Oh and if you are a fan of Game of Thrones then just get the game becasue you will not regret it!!  Enough said, buy it, play it, thank me later!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Oh where do I begin on a behemoth franchise such as Game of Thrones...Well first of all, I can probably say that you are not going to like this game, why you may ask, because considering this is a title released in 2012 you will be expecting it to maintain a certain quality about it which it sadly lacks. Allthough my complaints are few and mainly focused around the camera being centered to close to the protagonists back, I do not believe people who dislike this game are wrong.To break it down, the one point people seem to agree upon is that the story is what drives this game forward, it's a very interesting take on the events taking place during the first novell of the "A Song of Ice and Fire" saga, all be it not entirely canon unless we've been kept in the dark on some major nuggets of information both within the books and the HBO show.The errors I've heard about it is that the combat is way to repetative, and many people dislike the way it's done. For you who have played 'Of Orcs and Men', the combat is very similar to that, as is the gear system, only Game of Thrones seem to have a bit more indepth inventory. I personally enjoy this combat style, but as my favourite parts of the books are the priesthood of R'hllor, and my favourite part of the HBO show is Connleth Hill, it's hard for me to look down at this game too much. (Yes, Connleth does do a guest appearance as Varys).Another issue I care to mention that I personally struggled with was the portrayal of women, and whilst I am not a fan of the heated pro or cons of feminism debatte raging online, let me just tell you that even I who generally doesn't mind exploitation or characters not being described to their fullest was shocked with how there seems to be no noteworthy woman in this game at all, but hey, atleast the protagonists are allright. (Warning, one of the voiceactors for the protagonists sound like coarse stone).So to summarise, as much as I personally enjoyed this game, it probably isn't for you. I can live with the poor graphic, a handful of bugs and an uncomfortable camera angle as I am so interested in Westeros, but I wouldn't expect many others to put up with so much. But at the end of the day, I really enjoyed the game, it was fairly lengthy if you did the side missions and it never felt to easy or to difficult. But if you against all odds find it in you to deal with all of these things I've warned you about above here, I strongly recommend the game simply on the basis that I enjoyed the combat system, and the story is good.That and I got to play as a servant of R'hllor so it was basically 90% me roleplaying as Thoros of Myr.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												My expectations for the game were low, but it turned out to be one of the best RPGs I have ever played. And I've played quite a few.It's impossible to escape comparisons to the first Witcher game, in good and bad. The game features set protagonists -- two of them, which you'll alternate controlling for the first 10 chapters, after which they'll adventure together -- and the role of the player is not so much to decide WHAT they do, but HOW they do it. This is a fairly rewarding affair, as each and every choice you make in dialogue is likely to have consequences. Often not large ones, but the game nonetheless does a very good job in acknowledging the player's choices.The protagonists themselves stand out even in the fantasy world, Alester being an exiled noble turned Red Preist trying to reclaim his lands and Mors a skinchanger brother of the Night's Watch. Alester can use many abilities tied to fire, most notably revealing hidden passages and other secrets, while Mors is able to take control of his dog, who can then scout ahead or execute stealth kills. Both are well-written, and the player is given enough power over their behaviour for it not to feel as though the story is simply something one pokes along.The story is of epic proportions. It took me nearly 60 hours to clear the game, though at the hardest difficulty I had to replay many a battle. This brings up one of my grievances with the game: Much too often, difficult battles would be preceded by long dialogue sequences which you'd then have to navigate through again if you died. Inexplicably, it's not possible to load a game during battle, even if it's clear you're going to lose, but are forced to exit to the title screen first.The game isn't exactly small, but the few locations you can visit definitely start feeling cramped once you've ran through them a couple of times. Budget constraints are evident in virtually every aspect of the game, again very similarly to the first Witcher game. Another similarity is the very inconsistent quality of voice-acting. The protagonists are well-voiced, and the game even features some of the cast from the TV series, but most minor NPCs are Staruday morning cartoon quality.There is a LOT of dialogue in the game, and that's what ate up most of my time playing the game. Unfortunately, a lot of that time was spent REplaying through dialogue, and not only due to the save mechanic cited above. The game employs a dialogue wheel, and each choice usually entails quite a bit of back-and-forth between the characters after the initial line. This often makes it difficult to predict what exactly will each choice make your character say and do. As yet another poor design trope, dialogue choices often inexplicably become unselectable unless you pick them in just the right order, and often it's simply impossible to ask a character all the questions you could without reloading, for no apparent purpose whatsoever.There isn't a great deal of combat in the game, but what little there is is very clunky and unvaried. There is a definite tactical element, certainly, and at a high difficulty you're almost guaranteed to find yourself having to reload and try different strategies after the current one led to defeat. But every opponent is basically just a human of one of the six playable classes, with just their armour, weapon and health varying, so it quite quickly starts feeling like you're just going through the motions with each fight. By the time the game was over I was only too glad to be done with this aspect of the game.Despite these problems, it's still a very good game. A gem in the rough, certainly, but a gem nonetheless. Definitely recommended for any lovers of story-driven RPGs. Quality of writing is high, and the story is even canonical, so here's your opportunity to add to the Game of Thrones mythos. :P

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												SPOILER FREE REVIEWThe Game of Thrones RPG isn't the perfect game, but it does have a perfect story. George R.R Martin helped write it and you can tell, especially with all the intrigue and twists and turns. The game suffers from annoying combat mechanics and there isn't that much to do besides the main quest and one or two side quests, but it is a perfect game for any hardcore ASOIAF fans.The story is great and you play as two main characters, and you visit many places throughout the game. The iconic locations are in such as Castle Black and King's Landing, you can go to Mole's Town as well. But most of the NPC in the game just stand around and offer nothing to the story but to make the locations look full of life. You can also hear the authentic voices of Joer Mormont and Varys, and the voice acting of the two main characters is great also. The combat is a good system, but the annoyance is being ganged on upon by 5-6 enemies at a time. Even on the easiest difficulty the combat was annoying, not hard, just a pain. Many times I just wanted to skip the combat and advance throughout the story. Levelling up is cool, and there are alot of cool items in the game. My character for example was weilding Ser Duncan's sheid, and you can even use The Red Viper's spear. Those items are included with the Weapon Pack DLC though. Each "Chapter" in the game has the main quest and 1-2 side quests you can do. Side quests usually help you out later with the main quest if you accomplish them. But once you complete the quests there is nothing to do in the game but maybe fight in the arenas to get more cash. Making cash is easy, just sell all the stuff you don't have. No need to really fight for it. The game is great for all ASOIAF and GOT fans to enjoy. The story is great and you will feel for the characters, but just remember in GOT their is no such thing as a happy ending.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
Game of Thrones - The Roleplaying Game,...realy not that bad after allThis game is much better than its reputation. The characters are believably written and very memorable. Overall, the story is realy great. You don't have to have read the books, though it might help understanding the ovarching lore a bit better. Technically the game realy isn't that great. The animations are stiff, the voice acting isn't top notch and so are the graphics. But you have to remember that the budget wasn't very high. The game is perfectly playable, though the battle system takes a little time to get used to. The further I got the more I enjoyed it. Please don't stop after one or two chapters. I realy enjoyed the 29 hours it took me to complete the game(including the prequel DLC "beyond the wall"). For some players it might be important to know, that the game is more heavily based on the books than the TV Series. There are two characters (Jeor Mormont and Varys) that resemble the actors of the HBO series and are voiced by them, but that's it. Most locations don't resemble the ones you might know from TV. King's Landing has more of an european Middle-Age-Vibe to it, for example. Of course there's the ingenious Theme.The game takes place during the first book/season, so you won't spoil yourself anything that takes place after that time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												I have mixed feelings on this game. Story-wise, it remains loyal to the series and introduces new characters as well as characters from the show (with some of the actual cast providing voices!) Basically, the game is set in a similar style to the books. You play as two characters, Mors, a ranger of the Night's Watch, and Alester, a red priest who has returned from Braavos to reclaim his father's seat as Lord. You switch between both characters  every chapter. The RPG elements are great, allowing you to choose your style of play. Mors and Alester have different fighting styles, and you can pick which path you want them to go down. You can upgrade your skill tree, add points to weapons etc... all the typical RPG things. What ultimately kills it however is the combat system.  When you engage in battle you select an enemy and you can line up attacks. Using such an old combat model for this type of game is its downfall. I could look past some of the other aspects except this.Performance-wise, the game is stable and runs smoothly. The graphics are dated, but they're not bad so to say. Just don't expect super beautiful graphics. The enviroments are also a bit shallow. Riverspring, during the riots felt a bit bland to my taste. There was none of that true hateful spirit! You need to play the game to see for yourself. Apart from that the game hasn't aged well. It feels like it was made back in 2000. But what about the story? The thing that made me a big fan of GoT is the story, which in this case this game has remained loyal to. The game takes place before the events of the first book, in a simpler time when Robert Baratheon was still whoring away, Eddard Stark's head was still on his shoulders and the realm was finally in peace after the downfall of the Targaryens. Some of the cast members from the show lent their voices! I was absolutely surprised when I heard Varys' spidery voice narrating the intro and good ol' Jeor Mormont giving orders to the Night's Watch. It's those little things that make this game so special. It has it's flaws but if you are willing to overlook the outdated game mechanics, I recommend this. It's a must-get for any true GoT fan (It's better for readers of the book, but show-watchers are welcome to try it!) If you want a proper quality GoT experience, play Telltale's Game of Thrones game. There is far more polish and TV-esque story than this. EDIT: Oh and I forgot to mention the voice acting. Apart from the cast who lent their voices (which sound just like in the show!) some of the voices can sound uninspired, like when they're saying, "OH MY GOD WE'RE GONNA DIE!" They sound sort of bored. Not all the voices are like that, but some definetly are.

												(+) George R. R. Martin again wrote a great story, with great twists and many dead characters as usual. The storyline runs parallel to the main story of the first book and they almost touch sometimes. It's a tragedy as close to the book as possible without just telling the same story or object it.(-) The technical realisation is awful. The fighting system is interesting but gets pretty boring after a few fights. The skill tree is unbalanced, you got some really strong abilities on one hand, but many are pretty useless. The settings are often really small (Kings Landing is explored in 5-10 mins). The graphics aren't that good also, not totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥, but they don't fit a story so mighty. Also you get about 10 different weapons and armaments for every class, but except for a few legendarys they are all the same and you end up fighting Lannisters, while wearing a Lannister-breastplate, because thats the best you get for quite a while, but you hate it since you are a ranger from the Wall. But only in the very late game you have enough gold (and the chance to visit a trader) to buy some legendary stuff. All in all there are some heavy issues with how the epic story is implemented and it's really sad, because with a little more budget and a little more time this game could have been awesome.(->) Anyway: I liked the game because of it's great story which made up for all the pain I suffered while playing. I think I won't play it again even if i want to check out some different classes (haven't played the archer yet), but it's just too boring if you know whats going on.If you are a GoT fan or even read the books you should consider buying this piece (at least on sale!), because it tells a George R. R. Martin story in the universe of GoTl, that you can't buy as a book.

YouTube™ Video: Game of Thrones (2012 RPG) - Review 

			Views: 146		

			Title: Game of Thrones Genre : Role-playing game Developed by : Cyanide Studios Published by : Atlus Date Of release : June 8, 2012		

The game-play of this game is not all that amazing, witch can be condemnation from the word go to some people, but it's not beyond quality. The combat wasn't repetitive,  enough, the game's world wasn't linier and small enough to make me want to quit.  Despite all it's flaws, the story is the best part of the game, i would say it's on par with the TV series, and it was more than enough to motivate me to invest about 20 hours or so it took me to finish it. I guess the question you have to ask yourself is, are the kind of person who can forgive not so great mechanics for a story ? If no, then don't bother. Otherwise if you ever see it on sale, and  don't mind a game that is overall only slightly above average, then go ahead.

												As others have stated this is definitely a story driven game. On the story alone I would recommend GOT. At first I was not impressed with the combat but as the game progressed and the 2 heroes united I felt the game take on a different tone. At first I thought NO. however during my game I rethought that and even though I would not immerse myself in the dialogue as I did It still may be fun trying the different combat stances and actually striving to finish all the side quests. I also think of bang for the buck(joy for the price) and since I bought GOT at a huge discount I definitely got my moneys worth for 1 play and if I do come back in a month or more than the bang will only increase.

												A very casual RPG. It definitely doesn't comply with current standards when it comes to graphics and gameplay; despite being just a couple of years old it kind of feels like it was made a decade ago. But the story is very engaging, and it compels you to keep playing just to know how it unfolds. Much like the books (or TV series), not everything turns out the way you think. And the ending is so epic. The game is a bit slow at first but it gets better as you progress; and it's long enough for a casual RPG.It's not a bad attempt to translate the franchise to video game format. It's definitely worth a try.If you're a fan of the franchise, or if you're really into RPGs, you must play this game. Otherwise I recommend you to only buy it when it's on a sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 4, 2012
												A very solid RPG similar to Dragon Age, with some rough edges, but solid systems and a very rewarding experiance overall. The game fits in perfectly with the Song of Ice and Fire universe, without wasting too much time on needless fan-service. You will see some familiar faces, but the story is completely it's own creature and you will grow to care about Mors and Alester as much as any of the characters from the novels. Troughout the game, branching options with real cconsequences pull you into the story as you continually try to choose the lesser of two evils, in true Game of Thrones fashion. The game also gives fans something the books may never provide... an honestly great ending, and a true sense of closure. If you enjoy RPGs and liked the books or the show, you owe it to yourself to pick this up.

												Well, as I've never seen the show... And I hadnt' seen reviews for this game prior to purchase... I mostly went off the description... Enough that i'm not just hacking through the game and ignoring it as i do in duller games... The combat is pretty nice, choosing when and how to order abilities and such is really flexible... theres a pretty good bit of look, not on the level of fallout or elder scrolls... but who needs to pick up and sell every plate they see... There's a bit of moral choices, Early in the game you decide the fate of some prisoners  based on talking to them and guards... Over all i really do like this game and it may tempt me to watch the show by the end, i'm already convinced i'll need to get the dlc and see how mors got his nickname...

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												The game is a mix of GoT epic storyline and Kotor combat engine.You assume the role of 2 noble characters that fight against all the corruption of Westeros.The game is great if:-You like Kotor-You like GoT-You like totally unexpected plot twists(A song of Ice and Fire style)The only problem with the game( at least with my style) is the lack of balance between characters.Their skills were opposites and i found myself changing difficulty settings between chapters.The 2 men don't complement each other well and one was OP'ish while the other one was frustratingly weak.(the first char you play is the OP'ish one)The story is,like A song of Ice and Fire itself filled with 2-3 characters you love and a army of evil and corrupt idiots that you want to turn into your darts target.The plot twists were really unexpected(really,the last thing you could expect) and characters *spoiler*(read this reversed) daed yats ot tnaw t'nod *end spoiler*Really great way to immerse yourself in the world,as the game was canonised by RR Martin himself.The near-turn based style complements the scene,putting fast paced action and slow motion scenes into the ...decently... made scene.Lacking the great graphic efects of ,say,Skyrim,it immerses the player through Story.Warning,you may experience dreams of torturing characters from the game,if that happens,DON'T PANIC!Its normal for Game of Thrones stuff.9,75/10.(Really,the 0.25 is about the characters whoose eyes i poked out with a hot iron.)*Note:i am not a psycho.These are just jokes.Treat them accordingly.

												Pros:- The story & characters are very well put together- Pausable combat, which is always a + for me- Interesting approach to abilities tree, with skills u acquire due your decisions etc. (although  sadly they don't affect your game too much)- U get to control a dog and sniff around - pure genius :)- At first, i didn't like the combat system. Posted: July 25, 2014
												The game is a mix of GoT epic storyline and Kotor combat engine.You assume the role of 2 noble characters that fight against all the corruption of Westeros.The game is great if:-You like Kotor-You like GoT-You like totally unexpected plot twists(A song of Ice and Fire style)The only problem with the game( at least with my style) is the lack of balance between characters.Their skills were opposites and i found myself changing difficulty settings between chapters.The 2 men don't complement each other well and one was OP'ish while the other one was frustratingly weak.(the first char you play is the OP'ish one)The story is,like A song of Ice and Fire itself filled with 2-3 characters you love and a army of evil and corrupt idiots that you want to turn into your darts target.The plot twists were really unexpected(really,the last thing you could expect) and characters *spoiler*(read this reversed) daed yats ot tnaw t'nod *end spoiler*Really great way to immerse yourself in the world,as the game was canonised by RR Martin himself.The near-turn based style complements the scene,putting fast paced action and slow motion scenes into the ...decently... made scene.Lacking the great graphic efects of ,say,Skyrim,it immerses the player through Story.Warning,you may experience dreams of torturing characters from the game,if that happens,DON'T PANIC!Its normal for Game of Thrones stuff.9,75/10.(Really,the 0.25 is about the characters whoose eyes i poked out with a hot iron.)*Note:i am not a psycho.These are just jokes.Treat them accordingly.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Its a great roleplaying game, plain and simple.  If you are a fan of the Game of Thrones series like I am, and like roleplaying games, its just plain neat.I really am enjoying being in the nights watch and seeing the ominous, thrilling wall that goes on forever.The combat is tactical not action.  The game does say that in the description, but I thought it would be somewhat twitch based, it is not.  You choose the actions of the character and they carry them out in real time, but you can pause any time and change and/or que up orders.Its a role playing game, which means you do get to build up your character, choose attributes and skills, buy, find, and equip different weapons and armor.  I love it.  Exploration pays off in finding new items, etc.The graphics are fantastic at the highest settings and at 1600 by 900 resolution.  I know that people criticized the graphics for the Xbox, but the computer version to me at least, captures the world perfectly.The dialogue and story is game of thrones, that simple.  Horrible actions, rough words, and intigue everywhere.  Do not let your children play this game.  The first quest is caused by some horrible, R rated actions.A few things could be better.You have to almost be on top of an item before you see it.  For example, you may see a bunch of crates across the room, but you have to walk over there and almost be touching them before you get an icon that there is something to grab.The game appears to be fairly linear.  I'm very early in the game, but its not a wide open world to explore, its more of a tight knit story to follow.  There are sidequests, and several neat choices in the dialogue, but this is a more linear game.Needs more actors from the series.  The only voices that I believe are in it from the series are Varas and the commander of the Night's watch, thats it.  Since this takes place parallel to season 1, there are so many others we could have met.  I don't know what other characters may be around, but even if we get to meet them, they won't be the same voices.Anyways, I don't what was up with the Xbox version, but the pc special edition version is a great game if you would like to enjoy Westeros for a little bit while waiting for season 5.  Right now its on sale for 5 bucks.  Its a steal!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 10, 2013
												Game of Thrones title is fully earned here - evil will triumph and the innocent blood will grease the gears of political schemes.Writing is the main course here - the plot takes place shortly after Robert Baratheon's death, when the king's bast... errm... illegitimate children are being hunted. We have two main characters with separate storylines and motives, but they will be forced to take part in the political events. The atmosphere is very bleak, treachery lurks everywhere. The game features some of the most disturbing scenes in gaming - done so well, that the worst one isn't even graphic.There are a lot of smaller and bigger choices to make, the consequences are often non-direct or delayed - but they have impact on the plot.The game is off-putting at the beginning - the visuals are outdated (though some of the textures, armors etc. look weirdly good) and the combat feels slow and boring. But if only you'll stay a bit longer, hopefully you'll find yourself in the story's grip. The graphics will still be awful, but servicable. Combat will pick up a bit though once you'll learn more skills and get more stamina to use them - it will still be a bit boring as it's very tactical and focues on disabling and exploiting enemies (at higher difficulty levels it's very challenging).Get the Beyond of Wall DLC if you decide to play the game - it's a short prequel and it's great.

												This is easily the most underrated game I've played in a long time, if not ever. The story, characters, and the choices available to the character are all fantastic, and are reason enough for me to recommend this game to everyone.It's not a perfect game by a longshot (the graphics are outdated, the voice acting can be pretty bad, the controls are odd, and the combat system isn't groundbreaking), but it's leaps and bounds better than other games that OXM gives a "10 out of 10" to. The fact that this game got such a low rating shows what's wrong with the gaming industry (People who praised "COD: Ghost's" dog segments hated the dog segments in this game, even thought they're far better).

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												I really Game of Thrones TV series, but after all those bad and mediocre reviews, I bought it at sale expecting a disaster from the GoT RPG. I was wrong, very wrong... Gameplay seems clunky and unintuitive at first, but with every new level and skill it becomes more tactical. The combat system resembles MMO games, player is not controling the battles personally, but he's putting abillities and attacks into queue and the character executes them in the given order.  You have to think about, what abillity you use and when, how to combine them to give the highest damage possible. Enemies use abilities too, but with the right skills there is a posibility to interupt them or avoid taking damage. You can deal serious damage by combinig the right skills of yours and of your companions, on the other hand, if you distribute your skill points badly and just click on the abillity icons, you won't get far... The most exiting part of the game however is the story. The story is mature, dark and full of twists. Choices matters, and some of them may bite your a** later in the storyline. It's not about saving the world, characters have beliavable motivations and their lines are well written. I really love, how Cyanide made the plot lines of both main characters merge into one and how they fit them into the world of GoT, with events from series happening on the background. Bioware should takes some notes from this, about how to write a story.Even though it does not have the neatest graphics, voice overs of secondary characters are quite bad and there are few clipping and pathfinding bugs, I enjoyed it from start to the end, sometimes the story left me with my jaw wide open, which I didn't experienced in a videogame for a very long time.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												Game of Thrones is really an overlooked and underrated game on the field of RPGs. It tells a great story of 2 knights in the world of George R.R. Martin's Game of Thrones and fits well with the Book/TV Show. The game's strength is storytelling, and this is probably the problem for some percent of players, because there is a lot of conversation and narration in the game. Most of the game you will be running around and talking to people solving the next puzzle of the story (i would say around 70/30% for Conversations/Fight). The Fighting system is good (reminds me of Dragon Age) and there is a decent amount of skills, loot and customization to play with. The game is fairly linear but there are some secondary/optional quests to do as well as some minor exploration. The graphics is outdated but it works for me as it gives a good overall feel for the game.As said the storytelling and the voice acting what makes this game great and worth checking. It will not spoil the show/book just minor part, but i would recommend watching Season One at least to understand some parts and "easter eggs".Game of Thrones may not be the best RPG on the world but it’s definitely a worthy one. It requires patience and I would mostly recommend for players who prefer the story instead of the action. Try It out and May the Seven watch over you!7/10

												Yes, this game feels outdated, rushed and unpolished. The combat system is mediocre at best, there are lots of lengthy cutscenes with bad picture composition and lame voice acting (there are exceptions to the rule of course) and this is nowhere near your random favorite top notch RPG in terms of production value. But still, I found this game to be really entertaining and rewarding since the story was very well executed. I really recommend this game to any fan of the A Song Of Ice and Fire / Game of Thrones franchise, but keep in mind that you are playing this one for the story alone and not some fancy eyecandy. And while you're at it, grab the Beyond the Wall DLC as well, it may be short but it makes an excellent addition to the background story of one of the main characters in the game.

												I am going to speak of this game as a game. I will not compare it to the books, or the show. All things that are similar to Game of Thrones (Show/Book) will be, by this review, be considered coincidence. This game is very good. It has an excellent plot, interesting and creative story and good voice acting. The gameplay, however, is quite lacking when compared to other games, the right click to turn being quite unwieldy and difficult for new players, and incredible overlooks on the part of the developers, such as how you can walk through the actual, physical part of a door if it is open. The mechanics with actual combat are better, allowing you to slow time and use ability, which is really cool. Again, however, this game succeeds much more with story. If you like great story and characters, this is a good game, and I reccomend it. 8/10

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												From http://www.dyle.org/blog/?p=187:Finished Game of Thrones last Thursday. Even though the game has a decent story it bursts and get shattered on the shortcomings of the graphics engine.You play two characters: Mors, "the butcher", Westford, a loyal warrior of the Night's Watch and Alester Sedwick struggling to regain his heritage as Lord of Riverspring after been away for 15 years.The story is really great and contains all the ingredients the famous Game of Thrones series features: honor, love, fights, betrayal, debauchery, violence, mystic and magic, deception, heroism, and cruelty. It's all in there. This is a true Game of Thrones story.Also if you watched the TV series you'll recognize some characters: Cersei Lannister plays the plotting ♥♥♥♥♥ and you simply can't get behind Lord Varys motives and schemes. As a goodie: you have a Cameo-appereance of Mr. "Game-of-Thrones" himself: George R. R. Martin is the Maester of Bergholz. Running a little Q&A with him is quite hilarious.Ok, there are some irrational items in there: e.g. it takes you 3 months game time to travel from Castle Black at the Wall down to the Riverlands, but after chapter 8 you are free to simply click anywhere on the map and are there within a blink of an eye.Or: at some point Alester murmurs to himself: "pillagers will be executed" during a riot ... which does not keep you away to grab and loot anything which is not nailed down. =)But then there is the story. And what a story it is! I can remember the events in chapter 11 leaving me with my jaws wide open: WTF! The game overdoes this theme and attitude of the core Game of Thrones nature in the end like in the final events in chapter 14, but all-in-all it is a great story to experience. Westeros is here.This is the very strong part of this game.Then the combat techniques is quite interesting and has some charm: like in a Dragon Age 2 manner you slow down time - it actually never stops - and issue some actions. This interface is not that easy to get your hold on but after some encounters you'll learn this new experience. And it is fun. As time does not stop you feel pressure to get to your decisions rather fast. I finished the game on normal level and every now and then I lost some combats and this is a real good experience. Be demanding so that success is sweeter.This is the interesting part of the game.... and then there is the game engine. They say it does not take a good graphics for a great game to tell thrilling and fascinating story. True. But the engine should at least bare some minimums. This game is an example to stress this principle. As the audio and speakers are ranging from ok (average peasant) to excellent (Lord Varys) the Graphics are weak. All in all the textures are squishy, some motions clumsy. You find a lot of people sharing the very same faces and if I don't know it better I would say I've been witness to the impossibility of the framerate dropping below 0! Seriously, you have to be very capable of suffering and be very high pain tolerant accepting this. Walking around the great hall in Castle Black is ... well ... demanding. Even though some places are nicely rendered like the Gift at the Wall.If the developers had more time to improve the graphics engine this game would have been rated much higher in the critic's world.This is the very poor, ugly part of the game.For the record, I needed about 36 hours at normal difficulty level and finished the story with Mors taking care of the baby outside of Westeros.I award this game 3 out of 5 stars, thanks to the pretty cool Game of Thrones story line ... nearly ruined by the half-baked graphics textures and graphics engine. It could have been better. Much better.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2013
												I was hesitant to try this game because of negative reviews, but GOT RPG is now one of my all-times favorites. The story follows the lives of two war heroes, Alester Sarwyck and Mors Westford, after Robert Baratheon has taken the throne. Over and over I found myself asking, "What would Mors/Alester really do in this situation?" These true role-playing moments are hard to find in many RPG's because of weak characterization or their choices lack meaningful consequences. This is a game about the inevitable consequences that follow from making desperate choices between loyalty to one's social order and a more personal sense of right and wrong.

												It's annoying how much this game got panned in the gaming media. I didn't play it for that reason, and that's a good 12 months of not-playing-it I want back!True, the graphics aren't amazing (but no worse than the likes of Dragon Age. Better, in some respects). The attention to detail is brilliant (I'm a massive pedant when it coems to ASoIaF, and even I only found a few things 'wrong' :p). Treat it like an interactive story with a few gaming elements, and you'll have a blast.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												A fantastic story driven game that will leave any fan of the Song of Fire and Ice series happy. This a purely story driven game that has the dark tone and twists that make the books and the TV series great. I will admit that the first few hours of the game is slow and it may straw people away from this game, but don't this game picks up the pace and never lets go. This game requires patentince and there are scenes that last for a very long time but are filled with great dialogue and even better characters. Many people complain that there hasn't been a great game that the series of Fire and Ice deserves, I would disagree with them. This game is a great compaianon piece to the world and lore of this sereies of the books and TV shows. This has a great and lengthy main story that will keep you on the edge of your seat. It was very hard for me to put down the controller once i started it. At over 20 hours it provide a lot of great sotry moments. Also the side quest do not detract from the story at all and adds an incredible amount depth to the story and the characters. If you do all the side quests it will add about another 10 hours to the game, I would recommand that you do so. The gameplay of this game is a little weak and has a very steep learning curve. I'm not the biggest stragiests, so when I found out that the combet requires to you really think, it took me a little bit to get used to. But once I put the effort into it it become very rewarding. The graphics are not that great but they make up for it in the art department and the ability to recreate areas fome the show and books. the atmoshere is thick with style and can bery nice to look at. The game play and the graphics are not what makes this game great though, that's due to story. Get this game for the story, you will be a happy camper if you do so.  If you're someone that does not care for stories in games and only worries about gameplay, I would reccomand that you don't pick up this game. But if you are someone that love an incredible, darkcharacter rich and lore heavy story then this is the game for you. Pros-An amazing story that stays true(for the most part) to its source materail-Two wonderfull main characters that are great to play and level up-Two intersting intersecting stories that clash in a really great momnet-Fantastic vioce work from the main characters of the game-A Lengthy story that will keep you at the edge of your seatCons-Steep learning curve-First few hours are slow -Console port with no grahpic options escept for resolution (that can be changed by going into the invidia control panel and fixing that yourself)9/10

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												I really Game of Thrones TV series, but after all those bad and mediocre reviews, I bought it at sale expecting a disaster from the GoT RPG. I was wrong, very wrong... Gameplay seems clunky and unintuitive at first, but with every new level and skill it becomes more tactical. The combat system resembles MMO games, player is not controling the battles personally, but he's putting abillities and attacks into queue and the character executes them in the given order.  You have to think about, what abillity you use and when, how to combine them to give the highest damage possible. Enemies use abilities too, but with the right skills there is a posibility to interupt them or avoid taking damage. You can deal serious damage by combinig the right skills of yours and of your companions, on the other hand, if you distribute your skill points badly and just click on the abillity icons, you won't get far... The most exiting part of the game however is the story. The story is mature, dark and full of twists. Choices matters, and some of them may bite your a** later in the storyline. It's not about saving the world, characters have beliavable motivations and their lines are well written. I really love, how Cyanide made the plot lines of both main characters merge into one and how they fit them into the world of GoT, with events from series happening on the background. Bioware should takes some notes from this, about how to write a story.Even though it does not have the neatest graphics, voice overs of secondary characters are quite bad and there are few clipping and pathfinding bugs, I enjoyed it from start to the end, sometimes the story left me with my jaw wide open, which I didn't experienced in a videogame for a very long time.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												SPOILER FREE REVIEWThe Game of Thrones RPG isn't the perfect game, but it does have a perfect story. George R.R Martin helped write it and you can tell, especially with all the intrigue and twists and turns. The game suffers from annoying combat mechanics and there isn't that much to do besides the main quest and one or two side quests, but it is a perfect game for any hardcore ASOIAF fans.The story is great and you play as two main characters, and you visit many places throughout the game. The iconic locations are in such as Castle Black and King's Landing, you can go to Mole's Town as well. But most of the NPC in the game just stand around and offer nothing to the story but to make the locations look full of life. You can also hear the authentic voices of Joer Mormont and Varys, and the voice acting of the two main characters is great also. The combat is a good system, but the annoyance is being ganged on upon by 5-6 enemies at a time. Even on the easiest difficulty the combat was annoying, not hard, just a pain. Many times I just wanted to skip the combat and advance throughout the story. Levelling up is cool, and there are alot of cool items in the game. My character for example was weilding Ser Duncan's sheid, and you can even use The Red Viper's spear. Those items are included with the Weapon Pack DLC though. Each "Chapter" in the game has the main quest and 1-2 side quests you can do. Side quests usually help you out later with the main quest if you accomplish them. But once you complete the quests there is nothing to do in the game but maybe fight in the arenas to get more cash. Making cash is easy, just sell all the stuff you don't have. No need to really fight for it. The game is great for all ASOIAF and GOT fans to enjoy. The story is great and you will feel for the characters, but just remember in GOT their is no such thing as a happy ending.

												This game has one of the best plots out there, and for sure better than endless sea of boring like "Skyrim". I was charmed by drama and tough choices no other RPG could offer me in recent years, by characters actually playing instead of so popular nowadays standing and giving dull speeches (like in any Bethesda product), by giving the evil character that you can, from one side understand and from the other, want to slaughter without any mercy. Yes, yes... this game gives many emotions to a player. Character development options are quite good, with very nice extent of variety. Two characters we have occasion to control present completely different trees of fighting stiles and additional abilities.Many complain about combat system... Actually any player who remember "Knights of The Old Republic" should find it very similar. Sure it needs some getting used to after mindless click-fest from game I mentioned on the beginning or other pseudo-RPGs but it is nothing players haven't already seen. Some battles actually need planing and are very rewarding.Graphics. Yes, this game has outdated graphics. Everyone can see this on screenshots so there is no point in describing it but I need to say that except rare buggy camera work there is nothing that interrupts our gaming experience. Mechanics are ok, there is nothing good or bad to say about them... I experienced no major (or minor for that matter) bugs.So, bottom line... full price of this game might be too big for many players... but if it will be ever on sale with some good discount... then there is simply no reason not to take it.With regards,REDDQ

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												Contrary to what most professional critics say, this game is actually quite enjoyable.If you are a fan of ASoIaF and RPGs (and who isn't really?), getting it should be a no-brainer. The game is a stripped down version of a Bioware-style RPG with a focus on a linear and tight narrative. The game has very little dialogue and content outside of the main narrative; for example, the only rewards for exploration of the often large areas are coin and lore entries, both being fairly insubstantial. Typical RPG elements in this game like tactical combat and character building aren't particularly interesting, but neither are they horribly boring or badly done. But since it is not a strong suit of the game you might want to play on "casual" to not be bothered too much about it. The story has a nice flow, with familar themes from the books (or the show) being present while also managing to stand on its own. The game is told in alternating chapters of two different characters, engaging you in different aspects of the story. This is an experience rarely seen in video games, which makes this title stand out. The dialogues are usually pretty good, but if you expect the same level of wit, sharpness, drama and authenticity as in the books you will be disappointed. This is a narrative RPG, with the main device of narration being cutscene dialogues, so you can expect an unnatural amount of exposition in the dialogues. The voice overs are a mixed bag. The cast is quite good in parts, but some lines are delivered painfully slow and the actors often seem aloof from the situation at hand. You get the impression that each line was recorded separately. (Of course, this is how it was done, but the job of both writers and actors is to keep you from noticing this)The dialog system itself is similar to the wheel Bioware uses without the responses being pigeonholed into certain personality types. To make the choice between options more clear, the possible responses are worded in a more introspective style, often describing observations about the persons that will inform one's response or flat out stating one's motivation. This is actually a huge improvement over Bioware's use of the system, as it feels more like choosing the character's thought processes than just making a character conform to a personality. If you are a hardcore fan of ASoIaF you might find some details unbelievable, but for the most part the game's story and dialogues fit fairly well into the setting.If you ever wondered what a Bioware game would be like, if it was more linear and focussed almost completely on the main narrative, you might want to check this game out.Edited: I nominated this for the plot-twist Steam Award.

												Game of Thrones: RPG is a game i expected to be decent, but it turned out to be great. It doesn't really have much exploration, but a number of interesting side quests and hidden loot should keep you occupied. The combat system is very dynamic and well thought through, with skills of different characters complementing each other. Brilliant voice acting, likable characters and a thrilling plot with numerous twists and (as far as I know) four different, moving and emotional endings. I'd recommend the DLC pack, since the new weapons can give you quite an edge in battle, it lets you replace the skin of Mors' butt-ugly dog and adds a bonus quest that tells the badass story behind Mors' nickname  and presents some stunning visuals from the top of the Wall.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												Got that on sale, vaguely intrigued by its premises. Well, now that I just finished it I can say it truly is a diamond in the rough.Why a diamond? I'm a GOT Tv series fan (haven't read the books and I don't plan to, at least for now) and believe me, this game picks up all of saga's pace and spirit, bringing you a story which starts somewhat good and becomes even better and better as it unfolds before your eyes. You'll meet some of saga's main characters and you'll be hinted about others, but what matters is that Cyanide really crafted a very good story, with good dialogues and a good number of plot twists and secondary quests to keep you enticed. The two main characters, Alester the Red Priest and Mors the Black Crow, both have strong and complex personalities, and their backstories will intertwine in quite interesting ways.Why rough? Well, some players here hatefully despise its combat system. I don't. Sure, it isn't be the best around, but does its dirty job and it becomes rather intriguing once you get the grasp of it and once your characters acquire more abilities and powers. Characters animations and voices are...just meh. Could be better but also could be worse, nothing you couldn't stand. Ambients instead, unlike characters, are quite well designed.Camera may give you some headaches during combat, especially when you'll have to fight in tiny areas against many enemies. Nothing too shameful , just mildly annoying every once in a while.So, let's sum it: Do I recommend this game? Absolutely YES. Scratch under a layer of few and tiny drawbacks and you'll find a really worthy and fascinating story.Even full price is not too much, but if you happen to see it on sale don't pass it over, BUY IT.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												(+) George R. R. Martin again wrote a great story, with great twists and many dead characters as usual. The storyline runs parallel to the main story of the first book and they almost touch sometimes. It's a tragedy as close to the book as possible without just telling the same story or object it.(-) The technical realisation is awful. The fighting system is interesting but gets pretty boring after a few fights. The skill tree is unbalanced, you got some really strong abilities on one hand, but many are pretty useless. The settings are often really small (Kings Landing is explored in 5-10 mins). The graphics aren't that good also, not totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥, but they don't fit a story so mighty. Also you get about 10 different weapons and armaments for every class, but except for a few legendarys they are all the same and you end up fighting Lannisters, while wearing a Lannister-breastplate, because thats the best you get for quite a while, but you hate it since you are a ranger from the Wall. But only in the very late game you have enough gold (and the chance to visit a trader) to buy some legendary stuff. All in all there are some heavy issues with how the epic story is implemented and it's really sad, because with a little more budget and a little more time this game could have been awesome.(->) Anyway: I liked the game because of it's great story which made up for all the pain I suffered while playing. I think I won't play it again even if i want to check out some different classes (haven't played the archer yet), but it's just too boring if you know whats going on.If you are a GoT fan or even read the books you should consider buying this piece (at least on sale!), because it tells a George R. R. Martin story in the universe of GoTl, that you can't buy as a book.

												Cringe worthy dialog.False choices. (All options lead to the same outcome.)Grammar mistakes in item descriptions and quest text, several repeated sentence fragments in quest text. Several repeated sentence fragments in quest text. (Much like this line.)Scrolling the quest text is horribly slow, why do you write six pages of it if only the first is accessible in a timely manner? And why put new paragraphs at the bottom while starting display at the top? Each time the quest updates I have to scroll past the old stuff again. Very, very slowly. Excruciating.Slow movement, dumb, clunky controls.Zero combat AI aside from targeting a random enemy and spamming basic attacks.Every ability has to be used manually.The dog has a pointless attack ability that can be triggered for no extra effect over its auto attacks. The only difference is the icon. (bite vs sword)The auto attack uses the same sword ability that everyone spams by default (auto attack). Where did a dog get a sword from and how does it know to use it?Just when I get invested in my character I am kicked out into a new storyline where I had to make a new character.Several tutorial prompts trigger at inopportune times. Skinchanger tutorial should pop up after I assigned dog abilities. The first level 2 tutorial should alert the player to a new ability tree for their dog.Equipping items needs a tutorial. Right click item, left click slot, is that really the best way you could come up with? Smells like a console UI. Where is drag and drop? Where is auto equip? Why can’t I look at my equipped items in their slots?NPC dialog cuts out frequently.They interrupt each other, and break the main conversation. Or the main conversation overpowers NPC chatter.The first line of NPC chatter is always skipped. I barely hear the last word and cannot read the overhead text fast enough before it disappears. The remaining lines are fine.Dialog volume is not even 10% of combat volume. Barely audible. To compensate for this bug I had to boost Windows volume to 100% (Normally at 15%) and drag all volume sliders except for the dialog down to 5%. Combat still overpowers conversations. Of course the moment you enter combat all dialog cuts out. Even if the enemies are a courtyard away.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												I immedietly noticed this game used the actual soundtrack from the series and has some actors from the series actually voice act their characters in the game. That's a big plus. It's unfortunate that the rest of the game makes it seem as if the entire budged was thrown at exactly that, and everything else was rushed or just left alone. There's constant flickering in some textures. When starting combat there's a very colorful, mosaic-like plane on the sword for a second. A lot of the animations are rather unnaturally looking. Example of this is heads turning far further back than humanly possible. Walking pases are off, the lip-sync looks like people didn't even try to sync it.. Being someone familiar with 3D modelling and animation I can tell you that this is rather poorly done. The textures are low resolution, too. The dialogue is rather cringe-worthy at times and there are a lot of aspects that make this game not hold true to the actual environment of the universe. One immediate example is the Night's Watch. In this game they have good armour, a lot of food, halls are lit and seem warm. Whereas we know that the Night's Watch isn't being looked after in the books and the show. They need men, they need supplies; they don't have good armour. The dialogue, as mentioned before, is pretty cringy. Something that seemed odd to me was (close to the beginning) that I, as Mors, got to carry out the death sentence of the first guy I track. That's a commander's duty, not mine. I'm some ranger, a good one yes, but I am still just a ranger. Some of the dialogue options you get are really bad and don't keep you immersed at all. Everything just seemed very forced.The combat is rather lackluster. This kind of combat is good (like in Dragon Age) but it has to be done well. All of this combined made it very hard to enjoy any of the story.I know this isn't a great review at this point, I'll probably edit and fill it out later. But as of now I'd say don't get this game unless you get it in some bundle. I'm sure there are some people who could find enjoyment in this, but then again there are people who enjoy Goat Simulator P:  Jokes aside, I don't mean to bash this game; 3D animation and modelling is hard not to mention putting all of that together into a working game.Basically; some may like this and some may not. It depends on you, but I wouldn't recommend it. If you're really that GoT-starved that you need anything you can get, go for it.NOTE: my playtime is rather low, keep in mind I played this game offline, too.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												If you like the stories of Westeros, then I would say that this is worth buying when on sale. The story in itself is very good, though the game is no where near as polished as it should be. The combat can be clunky as whilst it isnt turn based (You assign skills in a slowed down real time), it can be very repetitive and there are often clipping issues where the characters will either occupy the same space or "vibrate" when they are standing half inside a wall. The system itself though is pretty easy to master once you understand the roles of each character (I always use Mors as a Landed knight and so he "tanks" whilst Alester can damage the enemy)The quest system can be frustrating too if you are new to RPG's as if you miss a slight detail, you will pretty much fail the side quests. Most of the side quests can be completed over several chapters, but if you miss a specific pickup that starts the quest in the chapter where it has become available then you won't be able to complete the quest once you have moved on in the story. This can be awkward for achievment hunters. I do wonder how this story would have turned out if it had been developed by a bigger studio, as it is clear that the writers have tried to keep everything in keeping with the lore of Westeros. It does kind of feel like this game was made by a company who snapped up the license before anyone else could and then they rushed to push out the game to cash in. All of that being said, if you are a fan of Game of Thrones and old style RPG's then I would recommend you buy this just for one playthrough. If you arent happy with slow turn based combat and linear levels, then I simply would not. I would also say that this game is not worth the full price and you should wait until you see it on sale somewhere.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												(if youre a got fan, dont read further the () part unless you like to be upset. i wanted to vent about this for a long time, now ill do it.first, you cannot ignore the fact that its a game of thrones game. that means that its basically a 'unconsented sexual intercourse'/woman-child-murder/incest porn in a mediocre, generic fantasy setting - with good writing. i watched the first episode of the tv show - that was more than enough - and as i remember it starts with incest and ends with a child murder; in the first two acts of the game theres a 'unconsented sexual intercourse' of a young man and a very young girl, but headless corpses and old women are also a fair play in the minds of the writers. im horrified at the success of the franchise, its one thing to write something like this, money is money but im amazed how many sick people are around to enjoy it. and this time there is no excuse like in the case of spartacus eg, 'we wanted to make it realistic, this is how it was', people, its a fantasy! yep, a 'unconsented sexual intercourse'/murder/incest fantasy. seek professional help. im aware that now i have angered about half the population of planet earth but i dont care much as i dont have a high opinion of the human race anyway. i have a small excuse for playing the game, it was a part of a bundle, got decent reviews, so here we are.)i was a part worried, having played of orks and men recently and, well, i didnt like it much. however many problems with that (somewhat later!) game were not present in got.-the attribute/ability/skill/trait system was much more refined and i felt actually compelled to think ahead and plan for my two characters.-in got you have much more freedom (something i very much appreciate in an rpg), you can travel back and forth, find new quests or secrets you missed.-it is more pleasing to the eye.-voice acting was great in both games, with a few miscasts (for minor characters) i guess they had to ask the janitor to fill in,-path finding is much better in got, there was only a few times when the not-player-controlled-character stuck somewhere (although there was a fun moment when the dog was stuck on a stairs under mors, both becoming unmovable).-i played alaster as assassin, there wasnt much assassiny about him: couldnt sneak, and poisoned blades should be maybe used in more covert fashion. at least we had the hound...-as with of orks and men music wasnt very memorable but fit right in, nothing to complain about (uh, i guess maybe it was from the tv show soundtrack and it might be an anthem or something for got fans, sorry about that.)-sounds are funny when you approach a group of people talking, it starts and ends abruptly getting close or putting some distance between you and them. no worries, there are subtitles (which behave similarly btw) and they are on a repeat mode. you can listen in to every discussion you want.-here, developers decided to make better equipment available to you as you progress in the game, not to throw the best stuff at you in the beginning. how traditional, how dull (sarcasm, see ooam.)-the game behaved reasonably well while alttabbing, not rock solid, there were a few crashes but nothing too frustrating. however i always had to mute the game as it doesnt turn off the sound when its in the background. minor inconvenience.-and again, talk, talk, talk. and again, i like a good story, when the game isnt only about shooting, butchering (heh), blowing things up, but sometimes the game felt like a - somewhat - interactive novel. maybe i had problems only with the distribution of the fighting and talking scenes, im not sure, but in hindsight there were times when you talked for half an hour then ran around with the dog for half an hour then fouught for half an hour (half an hour=might have been much more).-at least you can skip dialogue lines and cut scenes. not recommended btw only if you screwed up something and have to reload, but still, - though a feature which is common in the past 10 years - big step ahead from ooam.-lenghtier than ooam, steam says i played 40 hours but considering my abuse of alttabbing its probably between 30-35.-this also had some frustrating points, like the mark on your map showing an exit to your quest often led to a closed portal,-or you could reforge that damned valyrian (or something) sword to anything - except for what i wanted, a two-handed mace,-or the clunkiness of the character/inventory screens,-or a lot of (small) things i cannot remember and cant check as i - celebrating having the game finished - deleted it immediatelly.i enumerated faults and only improvements to my not-so-good experience with ooam but do not fret: this is a worthy game. far, faaar from being among the best, but a solid experience, entertaining, well written and most of the time quite well designed.if you like the subgenre i think the deciding factor might be, where do you stand with game of thrones, the franchise. if you like it, im sure you will enjoy it quite much.if your stomach tends to turn on describing or even depicting of incest and the most hideous kinds of 'unconsented sexual intercourses' and most vicious murders - well this might not be for you.i enjoyed the story and the solid gameplay but im sure ill never want to do anything with got again. telltale got? im sorry, so long, and thanks for all the fishies!still, ill wave the 'recommended' flag, as this game is a good effort, a worthy game, and im sure that many people with stronger stomachs (god, seems theres a lot of them!) would enjoy.EDIT: 'unconsented sexual intercourse': you know what. quite hypocritical from valve, filtering the r word while selling a game which is full of it. urinates me off a bit.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 29, 2013
												This game has one of the best plots out there, and for sure better than endless sea of boring like "Skyrim". I was charmed by drama and tough choices no other RPG could offer me in recent years, by characters actually playing instead of so popular nowadays standing and giving dull speeches (like in any Bethesda product), by giving the evil character that you can, from one side understand and from the other, want to slaughter without any mercy. Yes, yes... this game gives many emotions to a player. Character development options are quite good, with very nice extent of variety. Two characters we have occasion to control present completely different trees of fighting stiles and additional abilities.Many complain about combat system... Actually any player who remember "Knights of The Old Republic" should find it very similar. Sure it needs some getting used to after mindless click-fest from game I mentioned on the beginning or other pseudo-RPGs but it is nothing players haven't already seen. Some battles actually need planing and are very rewarding.Graphics. Yes, this game has outdated graphics. Everyone can see this on screenshots so there is no point in describing it but I need to say that except rare buggy camera work there is nothing that interrupts our gaming experience. Mechanics are ok, there is nothing good or bad to say about them... I experienced no major (or minor for that matter) bugs.So, bottom line... full price of this game might be too big for many players... but if it will be ever on sale with some good discount... then there is simply no reason not to take it.With regards,REDDQ

												The combat was so bad I took a break. Eventually, I got used to the combat and just sort of accepted it. While this happened the story became even more interesting. Hence, it's a diamond in the rough. If you love Game of Thrones lore, you will love this game. It gives more choices than that dumb telltale ever will and doesn't leave a cliffhanger. I wish there's was a way to ignore combat because I found the story to be the only thing that kept me going. I enjoyed this game and there were times where I would say "One more chapter." and almost be late for work. Not a lot of games bring that type of mentality for me.
